security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown files. No executable code, scripts, or system access capabilities. The skill provides usage documentation for S3 upload components without any code execution pathways.

content.user_title: Add S3 file upload to your app
content.value_statement: Building file upload functionality for AWS S3 requires understanding presigned URLs, multipart uploads, and security best practices. This skill provides ready-to-use UI components, client SDK, and server utilities to implement secure file uploads in minutes.
actual_capabilities: S3Uploader UI component with button or dropzone variants
ClientS3Uploader SDK for custom upload interfaces
Presigned URL generation for secure client uploads
File type and size validation options
Multi-file upload support with progress tracking
limitations: Requires existing AWS S3 bucket and credentials in environment variables
Does not include actual S3 upload component implementation code
Presigned URL API route must be created by the user
Maximum file size is 10MB by default

best_practices: Use presigned URLs to keep AWS credentials secure on the server
Validate file types and sizes on both client and server
Set appropriate S3 bucket policies for your use case
anti_patterns: Never expose AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY in client-side code
Do not skip file type validation on the server
Avoid uploading large files directly through your server

faq.question: What AWS permissions does this require?
faq.answer: The S3 bucket needs s3:PutObject permission. The server generating presigned URLs needs s3:PutObject and s3:GetObject.

faq.question: What is the maximum file size supported?
faq.answer: The default limit is 10MB. You can adjust this in the presigned post conditions and the component props.

faq.question: How do I generate presigned URLs securely?
faq.answer: Create an API route that uses @aws-sdk/s3-presigned-post. The route runs server-side with AWS credentials.

faq.question: Are uploaded files public by default?
faq.answer: The example sets acl: "public-read". You can remove this for private files or configure your bucket policy differently.

faq.question: Why is my upload failing with CORS errors?
faq.answer: Your S3 bucket needs CORS configuration allowing PUT/POST requests from your app's origin domain.

faq.question: How is this different from direct S3 uploads?
faq.answer: This uses presigned URLs so files go directly from browser to S3, avoiding your server's bandwidth and processing.
